abstract: Editorial examines latest challenge to Affordable Care Act to reach Supreme Court, which centers on whether several religious schools and order of Catholic nuns must complete form notifying government of their refusal to provide employees with insurance coverage for birth control; suggests decision in case should be easy, given that right to religious freedom does not grant individuals or institutions veto power over laws they disagree with.
lead_paragraph: In a secular society, religious freedom demands respect and accommodation, not veto power over government actions.

headline.main: The Fallacy of the Latest Contraception Case
headline.print_headline: The Fallacy of the Latest Contraception Case

snippet: In a secular society, religious freedom demands respect and accommodation, not veto power over government actions.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
